SUNDAY SCHOOL SERVICES
**TELEGRAPHIC.**

April 29

This House today is occupied with matters of particular interest to the west.

Clerk's motion in favour of holding Parliament in November has been deprecated by Mr. Thompson, who points out that if held in November it will not be possible to provide for the passage of the legislation required. Hon. Mr. Thompson says that it is not the intention of the Government to oppose Joseph Friesz as a judge in North-West.

To-morrow Mr. Bourne will explain to the Government the difficulties in connexion with the settlement of the Canal lands.

Mr. O'Malley has been elected Mayor of Halifax by a majority of 300.

Seven hundred emigrants started at Montreal yesterday morning, and will set out via Port Leslie. They are superior class and well provided for.

The danger from a rising of Blood Indians persists.

The dispatches from Vienna describe the growth of Russian influence in Silesia as being very great, but the Austrians seem to be preparing for a war with Russia.

Despite the vigilance of the police St. Petersburg was shocked last Sunday night with an outrage, the story being that the Imperial family, judges, and government officials, if the conspirators can make good their plans are condemned to capital punishment.

**LOCAL NEWS.**

R. C. Wiggmore, confectioner, has removed his new store on the corner of Broad and Bay Streets, where he will keep hand and tobacco stock of our confectionery and cigars.

R. C. Wigmore has just received a large shipment of goods comprising dress goods in all shades, hats, gloves, ladies' Jerseys, boys' and men's suits, prints, wines etc., his ready made suit-cases are being advertised.

Major Jack Cotton, commissioner of the N.W.M.P. at Fort Walsh, arrived in Regina on Thursday. He went out next day and will spend some time among his friends throughout Ontario. The hearty welcome given him is an indication of the sympathy felt by all.

It is accompanied by Lord Boyle, M.W.N. by Macdonald.

H. T. H. Phillips, Assistant Inspector of Weights and Measures, commenced his duties last Monday. So far he has found the scales used by merchants too small before conditions have been remedied, and has not had any complaints to perform. In a town such as Prince Albert as far away from the sources of supplies, it is not the inclination of Mr. Phillips to be severe, but he will do everything in his power to see what can be carried out without causing hardship to anyone. In his instructions he states that if any violations of the Act are known he thinks that Prince Albert merchants will be ready and willing to comply with them.

John Conner, C. Robertson, J. Sanderson, and Wm. Jackson, of Carrot River, brought in a pack of foxes they fell this week and sold them to Russell & Davis, butchers, for the price of fifteen pounds for seven to eight steers, some of them being only two years old, agglomerated 3,600 lbs., and a polec of owns 3,500 lbs. Loss assessed on the property of Mr. Conner, and will find the cattle raised in the bin, which cannot be made to sell better than five cents or even Southern Alberta, the land of extreme bore and blazing blizzards. Mr. Conner states that as much completed in the settlement as that area under crop this year will show the same ease greater than last year. Wheat and oats are the principal crops grown.

A meeting for the formation of a cricket club will take place this evening.

RUSSELL & DAVIS,

M'INTOSH & GERFORD
STRAYED.

Strayed north from Humboldt, in November, a team of black ponies, one a mule. A boy with them, also a dog. These animals would be greatly appreciated.

Also a Canadian mare chestnut, with white face and feet. We believe we are doing kindness by bringing the same to the owner, as the animal is not likely to find its way back here.

JOHN HODRI, or
HENRY MARRION, Stage Driver.

Humboldt, Feb. 21st, 1887.

TENDERS.

The undersigned is prepared to receive tenders into his hands.

Friday, the 29th of March. XXXX Carrier Grounds to be delivered at the Indian Reserve settlement, and handed over to Mr. Buck Lake, as directed. If not Country Superintendent, Mr. Buck Lake will return them forthwith in accordance with the law.

Tenders must be submitted at once, signed by the person tendering, and addressed "the undersigned."

JOHN HODRI,

H. M. B. & CO., Pavers.

"Dress to order."

CATALOGUES FREE.

THE STAR KIDNEY PAD.

**Unuperposed for Tone and Quality.**

"Awarded Gold Medal."

L. VANKOWCHNET.

Deputy of the Superintendent-General
Department of Indian Affairs, Canada.

"**LATH, 75 cts. per bundle.**"

**SHINGLES,** **$6 50 per M.**

We are prepared to Contract for Buildings as cheaply as any firm in Town.

Builders paying Cash or giving good security for LARGE Orders, will have a reduction made.

**MOORE & MACDOWALL.**
VEN ARCHDEACON PINKHAM.

Ven. Archdeacon Pinkham conducted the morning service at St. Mary's and the evening service at St. Alban's Church on Sunday last, assisted by Ven. Archdeacon John A. Mackay and Rev. Mr. W. W. Taylor. The services were attended by a large congregation at both services, and the music and singing in keeping with the occasion. In the evening Ven. Archdeacon Pinkham preached a short but eloquent sermon from Matthew xxv. 29-30. In his closing remarks he urged, he had visited the Dairy Act Guild, which they, doubtless, had all heard of, and which he thought would make a profound impression upon him, called the "Vale of Tears," representing the great mass of the poor, crowded and surrounded by a multitude composed of all manner of people, the great and the small, the good and the bad, the rich and the poor, the sick and the healthy, containing the germ of history, the future of mankind, and manifested the willingness of Jesus Christ to forgive all those who asked for mercy. He spoke of the coming times to the failure of the Lord Being, His power, and thought that the world was in a state of confusion, with great talent, and humanity as a missionary, and the majority of followers of Christ. He said that only a sense of duty had compelled him to accept the position to which he had been called, and that he felt the presence of God would give him the strength and courage to perform his duties. He had received the congratulations of all denominations, Catholic and Protestant, on his appointment, but he felt that he had gained the greatest pleasure from the congratulations of Bishop Miller, because His Lordship had been connected with the denominations with the Archdeacon of Canada, never more so than during his residence in this district, as well as those of other denominations, and his return to France also the Bishop of Saskatchewan had already looked forward to.

CHURCH MEETING.

A meeting of the members of the Church of England in Prince Albert was held at St. Alban's Church on Wednesday evening last, the bishop designate in the diocese presiding. The meeting had opened with prayer by the Ven. Archdeacon of Saskatchewan, the chairman stated that the Rev. A. G. Wallace had recently been charged with accepting another position in the mission field, it was thought that the united congregation of St. Alban's and St. Mary's would select a minister for their services.

The Hon. Lawrence Clarke then spoke of the pleasure it gave the members of the Church of England here to see their future Bishop among them, and at some length discussed the question of the man who for nearly three years had most faithfully discharged his duties in their midst, the Rev. A. G. Wallace, who was now about to leave them, and how he felt that all would agree with him that Mr. Wallace had been endowed with an irreproachable character. The speaker then alluded to the past noble and self-sacrificing labors of Mr. Wallace and their deeply beloved friend the Ven. Archdeacon John A. Mackay, and concluded by offering him, on behalf of the united congregation, his sincere wishes.

The Ven. Archdeacon thanked Mr. Clarke most heartily for proposing his name, and assured him that he felt honored to have accepted the position, and that he never to sever his connection with the Church Missionary Society with which he had been connected for more than twenty years. After an amicable discussion the following resolutions were proposed:

Moved by Hon. Lawrence Clarke, seconded by Mr. Brewer, and read as follows: That the members of St. Alban's and St. Mary's shall meet next Monday evening, the 4th of May, at 7 p.m., in St. Alban's church, to discuss the manner in which an income shall be raised as
